contents: Should the U.S. go back to the gold standard? Proponents argue that it provides long-term price stability, preventing inflation. Governments cannot simply print money, flooding the economy and causing prices to rise.  The average yearly inflation rate from 1880 to 1914 was only 0.1%, while the average yearly inflation rate after the gold standard was altered and then eliminated, from 1946 through 2003, was 4.1%. However, economic data prior to the establishment of a central bank in 1913 may not be fully reliable.
